title: How to Move Furniture to Another State

steps.headline: Get some quotes from movers.
steps.description: Don’t assume that hiring movers will be more expensive than moving furniture yourself. If you’re making a long move to another state, having movers take care of your furniture can save you time and aggravation. You should ask several moving companies for a quote before settling one one. Cross country movers usually charge by the pound or load rather than the hour. Rates average $0.50 USD a pound. If you are renting a moving truck to ship the furniture yourself, expect it to cost several hundred dollars.

steps.headline: Negotiate with the movers.
steps.description: In many cases, moving companies are willing to consider lowering their rates if you ask. If you have a lower quote from a competing company, you may be able to ask another that you prefer to match it. You are also more likely to get better rates from moving companies if you can move in an off-peak season (fall or winter). Midweek moves may also be cheaper than weekend ones.

steps.headline: Hire a mobile storage unit as a compromise.
steps.description: Many moving companies can drop off temporary storage containers at your home. You fill the containers with furniture yourself, then the company picks up the container when you’re done and moves it to the new state. This can cost less than hiring movers to load a truck for you, while still saving you the headache of driving the truck cross country.

methods.name: Packing Furniture for Long Distance Moves

steps.headline: Rent a moving truck.
steps.description: Call or visit the websites of several truck rental companies to compare rates. Companies will make recommendations for the size of truck you’ll need, usually based on the number of bedrooms you’ll be moving.

steps.headline: Get a dolly and rollers or glides.
steps.description: If you’re shipping the furniture yourself, springing for the extra cost of the dolly will make loading and unloading faster and easier on your body, especially after a long ride. Rollers and glides can be slipped under the legs or bottom of heavy pieces of furniture so you can move them easily and without scratching floors.

steps.headline: Remove any parts you can.
steps.description: Unscrew table legs, handles, and similar parts that will come off. That way, you can pack more efficiently, and it’s less likely that your furniture will be damaged in the move. If you have any furniture pieces that you put together yourself, you can disassemble them fully for the move, then put them back together in your new home.

steps.headline: Wrap your furniture securely.
steps.description: Place blankets, pillows, foam, towels, or similar soft materials around your furniture. This will help prevent scratches and other damage. If you want extra protection, surround the pieces in plastic wrap or bubble wrap as well. If you have antique or fragile furniture, you can also box the pieces in sheets of plywood. Nail the sheets together to stop other pieces from sliding into the furniture during the long move.

steps.headline: Pack your moving truck.
steps.description: Start with the heaviest and largest pieces of furniture. Pack those into the truck first, placing them closest to the cab area. Pack in smaller items and boxes after that.

steps.headline: Decide if you want to purge some furniture.
steps.description: Long-distance moves are hard work. Sometimes it’s just not worth the effort or expense to keep a raggedy old chair or beat-up table. Instead, you could replace some non-valuable, non-sentimental items once you get to the new state. For instance, if you keep all of your furniture, you might need to pay for a larger moving truck or higher costs to a moving company. If you get rid of some of your furniture, you may be able to bring your costs down, and can buy some new pieces with the savings. Things like cheap desk chairs may not be worth moving. Expensive pieces like couches and accent chairs are more worth the trouble.

steps.headline: Sell furniture you don't want.
steps.description: You can post items on Craigslist or similar online sites. You can also go old school and host a yard sale. Let buyers know that you're moving, want to sell quickly, and are willing to take offers. This is a great way to raise a little cash and lighten your load.

steps.headline: Measure your new space before moving, if possible.
steps.description: You don’t want to go to all the trouble of moving a hulking bookshelf or wardrobe to a new state, only to find it won’t fit in your new home. If you have a chance, measure the height and width of doorways and rooms in your new home to double check that all of your furniture will fit.

steps.headline: Move during off-peak hours.
steps.description: If you’ve rented a moving truck to ship the furniture yourself, try to make the drive at night or outside of daytime rush hours. Getting stuck in traffic will increase your fuel costs and the amount of time the move makes.

steps.headline: Deduct moving expenses.
steps.description: One silver lining to making a cross-state move is that you can often deduct moving expenses when you file your income taxes for the year of the move. Keep all receipts so you can prove the costs. Follow the instructions provided with your tax forms or software, or work with a tax preparer to make sure you get the full deduction you’re entitled to.
